title: Gas Is Under $3 A Gallon â€” But That Might Be Bad News
description:
ðŸ“Š Regular Gas Price just dropped 6.3% year-over-year to $2.94.

In this episode of The Money Map, we break down what's really happening with regular gas price, how it connects to cpi: energy, consumer price index, consumer sentiment, and what it means for ordinary Americans.

All data sourced from FRED (Federal Reserve Economic Data) â€” the same data the Fed uses.

Timestamps:
0:00 â€” The Number
0:20 â€” What's Happening
0:50 â€” The Full Chart
1:30 â€” Connected Indicators

script:
$2.94.

Regular Gas Price just dropped 6.3 percent in a single year. That's one of the most dramatic shifts we've seen in recent economic data. In this episode, we're going to break down exactly what's happening, what's driving it, and what it means for you. Let's follow the data.

Right now, regular gas price stands at $2.94. One year ago, it was at $3.13. That's a 6.3 percent decline in twelve months. To understand why that matters, you have to see the full picture. This chart shows the complete history.

Watch how regular gas price has moved over the past decade. You can see periods of stability... periods of gradual change... and then these sharp inflection points where everything accelerates. The move we're seeing now is one of those inflection points. The data is moving faster than at almost any point in the last ten years.

But regular gas price doesn't exist in isolation. To understand the full story, we need to look at what's connected. CPI: Energy is currently at 281.4... that's up 0.9 percent year over year. Consumer Price Index is currently at 326.6... that's up 2.1 percent year over year. Consumer Sentiment is currently at 56.4... that's down 1.1 percent year over year.

When you put these numbers side by side, a clear picture emerges. These aren't random fluctuations. They're interconnected forces... each one reinforcing the others. And together, they tell a story that's more complex than any single headline.

Cheaper gas sounds like good news, and for your wallet, it is. The average American drives about 13,500 miles per year. At current prices versus last year, that saves roughly $150 to $200 annually. But falling gas prices often signal something deeper. They can reflect weakening global demand... meaning the world economy is slowing down. Oil prices are a leading indicator. When demand for energy drops, it usually means factories are producing less, shipping is declining, and consumers are pulling back. So while you're paying less at the pump... the reason you're paying less might not be something to celebrate.

That's the story behind regular gas price right now. The data doesn't lie... and it often tells us things months before the headlines catch up. If you want to see more data-driven breakdowns like this, subscribe and turn on notifications. Every week, we track the numbers that actually shape the American economy. I'm The Money Map. See you in the next one.

broll_prompts.hook: Close-up of a gas pump display showing price per gallon ticking upward, numbers changing, harsh fluorescent gas station lighting at night, photorealistic
broll_prompts.context: Aerial shot of an oil refinery at sunset with steam rising from industrial towers, warm orange sky, sprawling industrial complex, photorealistic cinematic
broll_prompts.insight: Wide shot of a long line of cars at a gas station, everyday Americans filling up their vehicles, a working-class neighborhood, daylight, photorealistic documentary
